title: Does one ever completely heal from narcissistic parental abuse? - Quora

response.answer_text: Thank you for this A2A, Christa. Here is my personal approach: 1) I figured my mother is off. To cut the long story short, I eventually ran a Google search for “toxic mother” and I hit on NPD. That was a revelation that burned my brain, squeezed and wrung my heart, kept me on the shakes for weeks and brought me to a point of extreme mental and emotional anguish that nearly killed me. My entire life had been devastated by that satanic creature. I also figured I had two options: fight or die. I decided to fight, so I moved to step 2. 2) I binged on youtube videos explaining NPD and the impact on NPD victims. Bookmarked those that resonated with me and later watched them again. 3) I found Quora and selected authors and individual accounts that explained the NPD behavior in meaningful detail. Validation does miracles for NPD victims who believe they are crazy, and are ostracized by the Narc and Narc’s allies. 4) I carefully planned and executed my No Contact strategy with my NPD mother. 5) I digested the losses that came with NC. 6) Gave myself time to grieve for the love I had never been given by my parents. 7) I searched for healing sources for: “trauma”, “PTSD”, “complex PTSD”, “vet PTSD”, “co-dependency” and many more. 8) I selected healing techniques I believed could work. In my opinion, policing your thoughts, feelings and behavior is the starting point, because all NPD victims know is how to be invisible and not feel their feelings in order please others. 9) I started to meditate every day. 10) I started to CLOSELY watch my thoughts, emotions and behavior and correct my routine behaviors and my responses to thousands of triggers. I do it nearly ALL THE TIME when not working – when alone and when interacting with others. It takes a while to learn, because NPDs victims are an emotional mess and don’t know how to recognize and feel their feelings. It takes a lot of self-talk. 11) I started to treat myself as a little child that needs to be nurtured with love. I had never been nurtured in my life, so it took me a while to develop the habit to pause, think how harsh I am treating myself and change my attitude to myself and the way I interact with others. 12) I learned how to ask myself: “Wait, tell me how you feel at the moment?”, “Wait, why do you do this?”, “Wait, why do you feel this way?” “Why…?”, “Why…?” Those questions take a lot of repetition every day, and need to be processed in the light of the abuse. Every answer needs to be seen in the light of the self-destructive patterns learned in early childhood. It is very hard to penetrate an emotional world that has been dumped in the basement of your brain and kept there for decades. 13) I learned how to repeat to myself: “You are number one in your life. You are not responsible for others.”, “You don’t need to fix other people’s problems.”, “You are not what you do for others. You are not a worthy person because of the things you do for others. You are a worthy person, period.” 14) I meditate. Every day. Even twice a day whenever I can. I know I have made that point in Step 6, but I can’t emphasize enough how important meditation is. It is the single easy access to the subconscious mind. No other tool gives that easy access to the traumatized mind. I believe my fast healing progress is mostly due to meditation.

Thanks for the a2a Christina. The steps for recovery are everywhere, many slightly different ones are flogged by every second empath to ever meet a narcissist. I won’t address that well light path. I’ll address the feeling inside. The feeling that WTF!! Stop. WAit. NoPE. NOT HaPpEninG. That indescribable Aarrtggghhhhhhh that is muffled and coming from the general direction of those feelings inside you. The avoidance I have inside me that keeps me from truely feeling those emotions. I’m afraid that if I accept that I was never loved and cared for then, it’ll be because I’m just unlovable or what if I am loveable but no one directly around me could bother to give a fuck. They just couldn’t be bothered and because of that I’m like broken as fuck. Wtf is that?? What now though. I know how broken I am. I’d dearly like to try the reciprocal love thing. It’s what I’ve always wanted. But I’m scared. No, im not scared. I’m fucking petrified. I don’t know how to be in a reciprocal relationship my normal is apparently abnormal and what if people can see that. Basically every doubt you could have about yourself I’ve currently got and the ‘I'm a good person’ affirmation that I e been given to counter 47 years of self doubt just isn’t cutting it. How long is this gonna take? I’m almost 50 and I’m starting from scratch. Well worse than scratch cause I don’t know how to live properly and so I’ve gotta fix that and every instinctual response I have needs to be changed and basically if we just change the core of me then I can start over from scratch at 50. Ok. Fuck it! It’s too hard. I try to be mindful, I try to be suspicious of people. But I’m just not built that way. I relax and become open and naive again. It’s my default. It’s too hard to change. I’ve had enough. I have this conversation with myself about twice a month. It talks a fair bit of sense. There are time’s when I agree wholeheartedly. I don’t have a fix sorry. It all seems just so fucking overwhelming. But I put my head down and keep plodding on as always. A lifetime of surviving has trained me well to survive this Ultimate Bonus Round. The championship level that’s awarded to only the most broken of the abused.

“Heal” is a tricky word. I don’t think anybody ever experiences emotional abuse, or betrayal, and isn’t changed. Really bad shit happened, and that will always be true. But if “heal” means, despite everything that’s happened and all the damage that’s been done, someone can find contentment and joy and feel like life is much more than just pain, I do. One of the dangers, I think, is striving to always be happy. I don’t think it works like that. I think the expectation should be that bad things and bad feelings are still going to happen, but so will good things. Life is cyclical. If every time we hit a bad patch, the thoughts are “oh g*d, here we go again - I don’t know how much more of this I can take,” rather than, “oh g*d … well, I’ll just have to ride this out, it won’t last forever,” we’re not quite there yet. I don’t know what it feels like to be human when one gets a good start. But the people I know who seemed to have had decent starts in life seem to look at life that way. It’s probably easier for them, of course - the worst shit happened to them when they were old enough to have perspective about it. There’s no question that we have to heal ourselves, and that’s the worst part, isn’t it? The people who took on all the shit are the ones who have to then do all the hard work of offloading it. To say it’s not fair is an absurd understatement. Pretty Herculean. So I suspect it starts with grieving. And my g*d, there is so much to grieve. I do feel like, though, every time I let myself sit and have a good old-fashioned wallow, instead of trying to push the grief aside and keep plowing ahead, I feel better and lighter and (odd but true) cleaner afterwards. I’m pretty much convinced at this point that I’m going to have to feel the feels about things, when they come up, and feel them all the way through, to get rid of them. It does seem like doing that means I have long bits of “life is pretty great sometimes” in between them. My gut feeling is that the more grief I wallow through, the more of it I’ll exorcise, and the less of it I’ll carry around, tainting the good bits I do get. And all of this takes a consciousness. It has to be deliberate. Because I don’t realllly want to go to bed at night and revisit the trigger from earlier in the day and pick it apart and have to feel it all until I’m all feeled out. Can’t do it every time, either - sometimes it’s more important to watch Netflix and pass out instead. But some nights it’s worth the investment.

First, let me say I’m so sorry. Having a narc parent, to me, is one of the worst abuses there is. Be proud that you’ve taken the hardest step and gone no contact. That alone is HUGE. In my experience, my NEx turned some family against me with his lies as well. Not all of it will last. Some of your family will(hopefully) come to their senses when they start to see holes in his stories. The others? Well…some will never come around. My ex’s mother, brother and late-father all hated me. I never understood it as they never tried to get to know me AT ALL….even after 25+ years of marriage with him. What I realized much much later was he was bad mouthing me to his mother, who would then tell his brother…then the father…and so on. He was keeping them all away from me on purpose. He didn’t want me to be close to them, nor them to me. All our friends and family(sans my in-laws) have supported me and stayed with me. Here’s my advice. Know your truth…and be ok with that. He will continue with the lies, and there’s nothing you can do about it. Make your peace with that.

I think it's a long journey of two steps forward, one step back. I think we trust less easily, and are more suspicious of people's motivations and intentions. We build little walls..a small fortress around our hearts and enact stronger boundaries. We become very self protective. I think we choose more wisely people we let into our lives. We become cautious, looking out for hidden mines so we can avoid them. Is there happiness, love and freedom after —yes. It's rediscovering who we are, what we stand for, what we will and won't tolerate in our lives. It's all about looking forward, having good days and bad days knowing that we are okay. It takes commitment and courage and loving yourself along the way. It takes smiles, hugs, and a support system. Have faith in yourself and truly believe there can be healing and that you will find it :) Be the person nurturing you that you wanted in your parents as a child and did not receive.

Really happy for you that you have shown this type of courage. I fully understand that it was not easy but the future holds a lot of happiness for you. These are my suggestions: Let this be a new beginning. Whoever does not wish to form part of your life is not your problem. They made their decision, so respect it.Be careful to always stay off the radar of the narcissist. He will still try to find ways how to hit at you. Both directly and indirectlyKeep in mind your health comes first right now. You come first right now. You need to learn to love yourself with an intensityStay away from toxic people. Just walk away.Never allow anyone, whoever it may be to show any lack of respect in your regardKeep in mind that the narcissist hates you because to his mind, he owns you and you are indebted to him all your life to give him supply.Seek professional help if you feel that you need it. Try to seek someone well versed in narcissism.Seek to build true friendshipsBuild enough courage to forgive the narcissistAllow yourself alone time to process your traumaSpoil yourself when you feel you deserve it.Read and practice self love and appreciate the awesomeness of YOULet the narcissist’s mission to destroy you become your daily motivation. He will hate to see you happy.Share your experience here on Quora. You will help other survivors, but most of all, you will be helping yourself to understand what happened and to healPractice positive attitude in all circumstancesIf I can help in any way, please tell me. Really proud of you!

By forgiving them, how can you have hatred for someone that is sick, we all make mistakes in our life. If you are a Christian then God demands that we forgive one another, if you want God to forgive you for your sins then you first must forgive those who have sinned against you, and this will give you some closure to the past. You turned your family away, instead of helping them deal with your sick parents, you cut them off, having bad parents dose not entitle you to be a bad son, that would make you no better then them.I was abused by both parents growing up, and over time I forgive them,actually I was reading the bible and God told me that I needed to forgive them,so that I could move forward. forgiving benefits you, it means your giving it to God to judge them,when I forgave my parents it was like a ton of bricks were lifted from me, I know take care of my mother that abused me for years, and I have no hatred, I will not let my past define the person I am, and I will not repay evil for evil, her days are numbered on earth and I want her last days to be happy ones, so I shower her with love, and compassion. Life is to short to have hatred, I hope you find forgiveness in your heart,for your parents, and come together with your siblings and family, at the end of the day its all about love, I wish you well.

It is what they do. Don’t fight it, it will only get worse if you do. Go no contact with them all. It is better to be alone than in bad company. Don’t give your time and love to those who don’t give their time and love to you. I know it hurts, but playing their game can only be played by their rules and you won’t find your happiness that way either. I realized that I didn’t really answer your question. Their narcissism is part of who you are. I don’t believe you can fully heal because it would mean recreating yourself. Without a frontal lobotomy or amnesia, I don’t know how one could accomplish that.
